div.p: Greetings and blessings. Reverend man and dearest brother. I am sending this letter with this Englishman, who came to me in Thurgau, as we were returning to the Elbe. I wrote it to inform you that the longer letter, which I hear you gave to the physician from Jülich, was not delivered to me. I know that many are plotting against our letters and that they are being spread, whether true or fabricated, in the name of Calvin, yours, and mine. Therefore, I would like you, if you are going to send anything, to entrust it to known men whose trustworthiness you have proven. I see that I am returning to great dangers. But after the death of my wife, it is necessary for me to settle some domestic affairs. I commend myself and the church to God. Farewell. On the day of Bruma. In Thurgau.
To the Reverend man, distinguished in learning and virtue, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, his dearest brother. In Zürich.
